Graphical abstract Improving the resistance to alkali metals poisoning of commercial V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst could significantly enhance its service life. In this work, a simple method of incorporating P species was developed to enhance the resistance to Na species of commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 (V-Mo/Ti) catalyst. XRD and N2-adsorption results proposed that P adding have no obvious influence on the structure of V-Mo/Ti. However, the results referred from the H2-TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD and NH3-DRIFTS suggested that Na species preferentially reacted with P species than V2O5 species, which preserved most of redox sites (V = O structure) and acid sites (V−OH structure) on V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst. Thus, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti presented a much higher NH3-SCR activity than V-Mo-Na/Ti. Finally, possible promotional mechanism of P modification on improving Na resistance of V-Mo/Ti catalyst was proposed. We expect this work could contributed to the studies on preparing high effective NH3-SCR catalysts. Keywords V-Mo/Ti catalyst NH3-SCR Phosphorus modification Na-resistance 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions from coal fired power plants could contribute to the formation of acid rain, ozone depletion and photochemical smog, thus causing great harm to the ecosystem and human health. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with NH3 over de-NOx catalyst is the most efficient technology for NOx abatement, and has been used globally in the last decades [1–3]. V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst is acknowledged as the major type of de-NOx catalyst in the industrial application because of its high catalytic activity, good resistance to SO2, and excellent N2 selectivity [4,5]. Generally, the catalytic activity of V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst would decline gradually during the actual SCR process [6,7], because the elements in flue gas including alkali metals (K, Na), alkali-earth metals (Ca, Mg) and heavy metals (As, Pb) could poison catalyst. Among them, the alkali metals were considered to be the most influential substance [8,9]. Therefore, the development of catalyst with high resistance of alkali metals is a topic of enormous importance. Up to now, various methods have been attempted to enhance the alkali metal resistance of the V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst. For instance, Cao et al. [10] screened the effects of doping Ce4+ and Zr4+ on V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. It was reported that the co-doping of Ce4+ and Zr4+ led to the enhancement of NOx conversion and K-poisoning resistance of the catalyst. Chen et al. proposed that the addition of Ce(SO4)2 could strengthen the surface acidity and redox ability of the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst [11]. As a consequence, the V2O5-Ce(SO4)2/TiO2 catalyst exhibited improved resistance to Na poisoning. Li’ group tried to enhance the alkali metal resistance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst by adding Ce and Cu, and found that the synergistic effect of Ce-Cu could maintain the surface acidity and redox properties of VWCeCuTi-K catalyst [12]. Recently, the enhancement of alkali metal resistance of de-NOx catalyst by adding phosphorus has excited interest, despite phosphorus is usually recognized as a harmful element to the de-NOx catalyst [13–16]. The introduction of phosphorus by impregnation [17], sol-gel [18], and solvothermal methods [19] were proved to be beneficial for the NH3-SCR performance of CeO2/TiO2 catalysts. Phosphorus effectively increases the reducibility and surface acidity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Consequently, the temperature window of the catalyst is broadened and the tolerance to K species is strengthened [20]. With regards to the V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst, the introduction of phosphorus was also reported to improve the catalytic behavior of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst obviously [21]. However, there is little literature about phosphorus as a promoter for V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst in the improvement of alkali metal resistance. Inspired by these, we prepared the P modified V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The catalysts were characterized by several methods, including XRD, N2-adsorption, H2-TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD, and NH3-DRIFTS. The modifying effects of phosphorus addition to V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst on its physicochemical characteristics, catalytic behavior in the NH3-SCR reaction, and resistance to Na were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 (denoted as V-Mo/Ti) catalyst with a weight content of 1.2 wt% V2O5 and 2.5 wt% MoO3 was prepared by impregnation method. Ammonium metavanadate, ammonium molybdate, and oxalic acid solution were mixed under stirring at 80 °C for 2 h. Afterwards, the prepared sample was totally dried. At last, the sample was calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h. P modified V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 (denoted as V-Mo-P/Ti) catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. H3PO4 aqueous solution was impregnated to the V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst to obtain a paste followed by stirring at 80 °C for 2 h. Then the paste was dried and calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h. The loading of P species was fixed at 1 wt% (calculated by P2O5). 2.2 Poisoning of Na Na poisoned catalysts (denoted as V-Mo-Na/Ti and V-Mo-P-Na/Ti, the weight content of Na2O/catalyst is 0.5 wt% Na2O) were obtained via the impregnation method. The powder of V-Mo/Ti(V-Mo-P/Ti) catalyst was added into NaNO3 aqueous solution under stirring and stirred for 2 h at 80 °C, respectively. Then the samples were totally dried and calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h. 2.3 Characterization The samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Philips X’Pert3 Power diffractometer with a copper anode tube), Nitrogen adsorption (Micromeritics ASAP 2000) and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS, PHI 5000 VersaProbe). Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were measured in a chemisorbed measurement (AutoChem II 2920). Prior to experiments, the sample was pretreated in flowing He stream at 300 °C for 1 h. H2-TPR was carried out by heating sample to in 10 °C/min under the atmosphere of 5 vol% H2/Ar. For NH3-TPD experiment, sample was pretreated by sufficient NH3 at 100 °C, and then heating to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using He (50 mL/min) as the carrier gas. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of NH3 (NH3-DRIFTS) absorption-desorption was performed in a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 spectrometer, which was equ ipped with a Harrich IR cell and an MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The spectra of NH3-DRIFT were collected by accumulating 16 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to the experiment, the sample was pretreated with N2 at a flow rate of 50 mL/min at 450 °C for 30 min. The sample spectra were recorded at 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400 and 450 °C in the N2 atmosphere. Then, the sample was purged with 1000 ppm NH3/N2 for 30 min at 450 °C. After changing N2 atmosphere, the samples temperature was heated from 100 °C to 450 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and then recorded the spectra at 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400 and 450 °C. Finally, the NH3-DRIFT spectra were obtained by deducting the spectra of sample at the same temperature. 2.4 Catalytic test NH3-SCR activity experiments were carried out in a conventional quartz tubular reactor with catalyst samples of 0.1 g. The reaction gas with a total flow rate of 1000 mL/min is consisted of 0.05 vol% NH3, 0.05 vol% NO, and 5 vol% O2 in N2. All catalysts were kept on stream at each test temperature for 0.5 h. The composition of the reaction or product gasses was monitored continuously by a flue gas analyzing apparatus (Protea AtmosFIRt). NOx conversion (%) and N2 selectivity (%) were defined as follows: NO x conversion % = [ NO x ] in - [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in ×100% N 2 selectivity % = [NO] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [NO] out - NH 3 out -2× [ N 2 O] out [NO] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [NO] out - [N H 3 ] out ×100% 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations The XRD patterns of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . Apparently, the profiles of all samples exhibit only anatase type of TiO2 [10]. In addition, no obvious diffraction peaks ascribed to V2O5, MoO3, P2O5, and Na2O were detected, indicating the finely dispersed of the vanadium, molybdenum, phosphorus species, as well as sodium species, on the surface of the TiO2. Compared to fresh V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst, Na poisoned catalyst showed a stronger XRD diffraction peaks. This result could be attributed to the additional calcination process during impregnating NaNO3, which increased the crystallinity of TiO2 [22]. The porous properties of catalysts were studied by N2-adsorption experiments and the results are presented in Table 1 and Fig S1. As shown in Table 1, the BET surface area and pore volume of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst are slightly lower than that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, indicating that phosphorus loading had no obvious influence on structure of V-Mo/Ti catalyst. With impregnating Na, the BET surface area and pore volume of the fresh V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalysts decreased distinctly, because Na species could block the microspores of catalyst [23]. Fig S1 manifests the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of different catalysts. All catalysts present similar N2 physisorption isotherms that belong to type-IV sorption curves with H3 hysteresis loops, which is dominant in mesoporous materials with slit-like pores. No significant changes can be observed in the overlapped adsorption and desorption isotherm curves of the different catalysts, which indicated that the addition of P and/or Na could not change the porous structures of VMo/Ti catalyst apparently. XPS spectra of different catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 and Table 2 . The V 2p XPS results of the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 2a. After a curve-fitting process, the V 2p XPS spectra was de-convoluted to three peaks of different valance states: V5+ 2p 3/2 (517.2 eV), V4+ 2p 3/2 (516.3 eV) and V3+ 2p 3/2 (515.4 eV) [24]. From the data in Table 2, it is recognized that the V5+/(V3++V4++V5+) ratio of V-Mo/Ti catalyst decreased from 32 % to 27 % after phosphorus doping. Vanadium species from monomeric vanadyl exists in high oxidation states, whereas the polymeric phase corresponds to low oxidation state [25,26]. Yan et al. had proved that the polymeric phase of surface vanadyl species was significantly increased after P adding [21]. Thus, the decreased V5+ species could be attributed to the increase of polymeric phase of surface vanadyl species. After loading Na species, the concentration of V5+ ions on V-Mo-/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalysts dropped distinctly due to formation of V-O-M (M = K, Na) structure [12,27–29]. Furthermore, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst exhibits higher value of V5+/(V3++V4++V5+) ratio than V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst, indicating that phosphorus lessened the poisoning effect of Na on the vanadium species. Fig. 2b represents the Mo 3d peak of the different catalysts. The peaks at 235.8 eV and 232.6 eV can be ascribed to Mo6+, while the peaks positioned at 235 eV and 231.8 eV represent Mo5+ [30]. For all samples, the molybdenum predominates in Mo6+ valence states. The Mo6+/(Mo5++Mo6+) ratio of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst is slightly lower than that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, which is caused by the interaction between MoO3 and phosphorous [31]. In comparison to the fresh catalysts, the Mo6+/(Mo5++Mo6+) ratio in the Na-poisoned catalysts increased, accompanied by the decrease of the binding energy. The increase of Mo6+/(Mo5++Mo6+) ratio could be aroused from the formation of Na2MoO4. Meanwhile, the decline in the binding energy of Na-poisoned catalysts could be explained by the variation of Mo (VI) coordination state [32]. The XPS spectra of O 1s was shown in Fig. 2c. The O 1s peaks were divided into two peaks: the surface chemisorbed oxygen Oα (529.8 eV); lattice oxygen Oβ (529.0–530.0 eV) [33]. Typically, it is turned out that Oα is the most active oxygen and plays an important role in oxidation reactions [34,35]. The higher Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio makes it easier to oxide NO to NO2, which facilitates the “fast SCR” process (NO + NO2+2NH3→2N2+3H2O). On the basis of XPS results, the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio over V-Mo/Ti, V-Mo-P/Ti, V-Mo-Na/Ti, and V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalysts were calculated to be 7%, 9%, 4%, and 6%, respectively. V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst presented a higher Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio compared with the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, which is attributed to its higher amount of polymeric vanadate [36]. As for the two Na-poisoned catalysts, the concentration of chemisorbed oxygen on the surface of the catalysts dropped to different certain extents. This result is assigned to the formation of strong bonds between surface oxygen centers and Na [29]. Besides, the binding energy of the lattice oxygen in the spectra of V-Mo-Na/Ti and V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalysts moved to lower values compared with that in the spectra of V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalysts, respectively. This phenomenon is in line with the previous studies by Guo et al. [23] and Gao et al. [37], which could be explained by the strong interaction between Na and the lattice oxygen. Notably, the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio of V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst is also higher than that of the V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst. Fig. 2d illustrates the XPS spectra of P 2p of V-Mo-P/Ti and V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalysts. The P 2p peaks could be fitted into two peaks referred to P2O5 (134 eV) and PO3 − (133.2 eV) [20]. From Table 2, it is apparent that the molar ratio of PO3 −/(P2O5+PO3 −) for the two catalysts are all over 0.6, revealing that P species on the surface of the two catalysts are mainly in the form of metaphosphate. V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst presents a relative higher PO3 −/(P2O5+PO3 −) ratio, which could be consistent with the formation of NaPO3. In this way, the interaction between Na and vanadium species would decrease. Concurrently, the effect of Na on the catalytic performance of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst might be relatively small. The reducibility of the catalysts was evaluated by H2-TPR analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 , single reduction peak appears at 416 °C, attesting to the reduction of vanadium oxides and molybdenum species could be found in the profiles of V-Mo/Ti catalyst [38,39]. After incorporating with P species, the H2 consumption peak temperature shifts to the higher temperature region, illustrating that P addition decreases the reducibility of V-Mo/Ti catalyst. According to the literatures [21,40], this result is attributed to the increase of polymeric vanadate by P doping, because the polymerization of vanadium species could increase the difficulty of being reduced in H2 atmosphere. Additionally, additional H2 consumption peak could be observed at about 740 °C for V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst, which is ascribed to the reduction of PO bond [31,41,42]. In contrast with V-Mo/Ti catalyst, two H2 consumption peaks around 500 °C and 594 °C arise in the profile of V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst. In order to identify these two peaks, the H2-TPR profiles of V/Ti, Mo/Ti, V-Na/Ti, and Mo-Na/Ti samples (prepared by the method are exactly the same as the V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-Na/Ti catalysts.) were tested. As observed from Fig S2, V/Ti and Mo/Ti samples present only one H2 consumption peak at 415 °C and 386 °C, respectively. V-Na/Ti sample contains one peak in the temperature range of 400–550 °C. For Mo-Na/Ti sample, the H2 consumption peak appears at around 423 °C. That is to say, the effect of Na on the MoOx species is inferior to that of VOx species. Based on this, it can be speculated that the two H2 consumption peaks at 500 °C and 594 °C of V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst are ascribed to the reduction of MoOx species and VOx species, respectively. In other words, Na has obvious implication for the VOx species, leading to the decline of the reducibility of V-Mo/Ti catalyst [43]. Similar to V-Mo-Na catalyst, the H2 consumption peak of V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst also shifts to higher temperature compared with that of the V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst, i.e., from 429 °C to 492 °C. Clearly, it could be found that the H2 consumption peak temperature of VO x species of V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst (492 °C) is much lower than that of the V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst (594 °C). Accordingly, it is concluded that the addition of P alleviates the negative effect of Na on the reducibility of the fresh catalyst. The acidity is another vital factor in the catalytic performance of V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst. Hence, NH3-TPD analysis and DRIFTS measurements of NH3 adsorption were carried out to clarify the acidity of the different catalysts. Fig. 4 presents the NH3-TPD profiles of samples. All samples exhibit a broad NH3 desorption peak at around 425 °C. The ammonia desorption for V-Mo/Ti, V-Mo-P/Ti, V-Mo-Na/Ti, and V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalysts are 349.1, 305.2, 71.9 and 210.8 μmol/g, respectively. The amount of desorbed NH3 of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst is less than that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, indicating that the loading of phosphorus decreases the acidity of V-Mo/Ti catalyst. As discussed in Fig. 2, un-incorporated P species exists on the V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst, which might decrease the surface acidity of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst [44–46]. In the case of V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst, the NH3 desorption peak area decreases obviously in contrast with that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst. Unlike the poor acidity of V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst possesses a broad NH3 desorption peak from 320 °C to 550 °C, and the peak area is higher than that of the V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the NH3-DRIFTS spectra of samples. Several bands ascribed to NH bond of absorbed NH3 (3400–3100 cm−1), NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (1600, 1240 and 1210 cm−1) and NH4 + on the Bronsted acid sites (1666 and 1430 cm−1) could be observed in the spectra of all samples [27]. Notably, the peaks due to NH3 adsorbed on Bronsted acid sites is disappeared more quickly than the peaks due to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites with increase of temperature. Combined with NH3-TPD results, it could be concluded that the weak adsorbed NH3 species (desorbed at low temperature) could be assigned to the NH4 + on Bronsted acid sites, and the strong adsorbed NH3 species could be ascribed to the NH3 on Lewis acid sites (desorbed at higher temperature). For V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalysts, the bands of adsorbed NH3 species could be seen in their spectra (Fig. 5a-b) even at the temperature of 450 °C. For the Na poisoned catalysts, the bands of NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites could be found at 400 °C. Notably, the peaks due to NH4 + species adsorbed Bronsted acid sites are almost completely disappeared at 200 °C in the spectra of V-Mo-Na/Ti sample. However, for V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst (Fig. 5d), the signal of the Bronsted acid sites could be remained until 350 °C. These results suggest that Na could interact with surface acid sites (priority to interact with Bronsted acid sites) on V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti catalysts, and then inhibit the NH3 adsorption. Furthermore, combined with the XPS and NH3-TPD results, it could be concluded that P species could inhibit the destroy effect of Na species on surface acid sites by preferentially interacting with impregnated Na species. 3.2 NH3-SCR activity Fig. 6 a shows the NH3-SCR activity of samples at the temperature range of 250–430 °C. V-Mo/Ti catalyst exhibits relatively narrow operating temperature window, 80 % NO x removal efficiency could be obtained only at a temperature of 310–430 °C. The phosphorus addition significantly enhanced the NH3-SCR activity of V-Mo/Ti catalyst at the temperature of 250–340 °C by decreasing the reaction activation energy (Fig S3), thus the operating temperature window with 80 % NO x removal efficiency was expand to 300–430 °C. With loading Na species, a sharp activity drop could be observed in the NO x removal efficiency of V-Mo/Ti and V-Mo-P/Ti. V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst showed a NO x conversion below 23 % at whole tested temperature. V-Mo-P-Na/Ti presented a much higher NH3-SCR activity than V-Mo-Na/Ti, and above 40 % NO x removal efficiency could be obtained at the temperature 305–340 °C. These results proposed that the decline in the catalytic activity caused by Na was effectively restrained by P modification. For further verify above results, the deactivation rates of the different catalysts with different contents of Na (a) and P (b) species. As shown in Fig S4, P addition could inhibit the Na poison effect on V-Mo /Ti, and the inhibition effect would increase with increasing P content. Fig. 6 b shows the N2O concentration and N2 selectivity of samples during the NH3-SCR reaction. For all catalysts investigated in our experiment, the formation of N2O tends to escalate when the reaction temperature is above 370 °C. V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst presents higher N2O concentration than that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, which is due to it possessed more amount of polymeric vanadate. Because the polymerization process of dispersed vanadium species is regarded as the main reason for the increase of N2O in NH3-SCR reaction [47]. In addition, it could also be found from Fig. 6b that the N2O concentration of the Na-poisoned catalysts were higher than that of the corresponding fresh catalysts. Similar results were reported by Tian et al. [43], which is related the fact that Na promoted the side reaction during the NH3-SCR process. Fig. 5 (c) also exhibits the corresponding N2 selectivity of the different catalysts. It is clear that the N2 selectivity of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst is lower than that of the V-Mo/Ti catalyst, which is due to the fact that the presence of P leaded to the increase of N2O during the SCR reaction. Apart from that, it is interesting to note that that the N2 selectivity of V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst is higher than that of V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst. This phenomenon allows us to confirm that the loading of P enhances the Na-resistance of V-Mo/Ti catalyst. 3.3 Possible promotional mechanism analysis The possible promotional mechanism of P modification on improving the Na-resistance of V-Mo/Ti catalyst was proposed in Scheme 1 by combining the results of previous studies and this work. Na species could react with V2O5 species, which decreased the redox properties of the redox sites (V = O structure) and the amounts of acid sites (V−OH structure) on V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst, thereby leading to the decrease of NH3-SCR activity. For V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst, Na species preferentially reacted with P species than V2O5 species, which preserved most of redox sites and acid sites. Thus, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti presented a much higher NH3-SCR activity than V-Mo-Na/Ti. 4 Conclusion In summary, the addition of phosphorus has significant impact on the Na-resistance of V-Mo/Ti catalyst for NH3-SCR. Compared with the catalyst without phosphorus, the polymeric vanadate and the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio of V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst were increased, leading to the improvement of catalytic performance. The loading of Na resulted in the decrease of the reducibility, Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio, and acidity of the catalysts. While the presence of phosphorus could alleviate the above-mentioned effects to a certain extent. V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst exhibits higher reducibility, Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio, and acidity than that of the V-Mo-Na/Ti catalyst. Because of these, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti catalyst exhibited relatively better catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Improving the resistance to alkali metals poisoning of commercial V2O5-TiO2 based catalyst could significantly enhance its service life. In this work, a simple method of incorporating P species was developed to enhance the resistance to Na species of commercial V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 (V-Mo/Ti) catalyst. XRD and N2-adsorption results proposed that P adding have no obvious influence on the structure of V-Mo/Ti. However, the results referred from the H2-TPR, XPS, NH3-TPD and NH3-DRIFTS suggested that Na species preferentially reacted with P species than V2O5 species, which preserved most of redox sites (V = O structure) and acid sites (V−OH structure) on V-Mo-P/Ti catalyst. Thus, V-Mo-P-Na/Ti presented a much higher NH3-SCR activity than V-Mo-Na/Ti. Finally, possible promotional mechanism of P modification on improving Na resistance of V-Mo/Ti catalyst was proposed. We expect this work could contributed to the studies on preparing high effective NH3-SCR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of phosphorus modification on improving the Na resistance of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3
